title-group.article-title: Motion control of an electromagnetic valve actuator based on the inverse system method

contrib-group.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, People’s Republic of China

abstract.p: In an electromagnetic valve actuator (EMVA), precise motion control is desired to achieve fully variable valve actuation, so that the fuel economy, the emissions, and the torque output performance of the engine will be improved. This paper presents an inverse system method (ISM) to achieve precise valve motion control for a moving-coil EMVA. The dynamic model of the EMVA is established, and the inverse system of the EMVA is obtained. By linearization of the non-linear EMVA system, state feedback control is used to control the valve to follow the desired valve motion. A state variable observer is designed to estimate the unmeasurable state variables. Simulations and an experimental set-up are used to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control method. The performance of proportional–integral–derivative control is compared with ISM control in the simulations, and ISM control is robust to large parameter variations of 50 per cent. The experimental results show close agreement with the simulation results. The proposed method proved effective by achieving a transition time of 3.8 ms and a seating velocity of 0.05 m/s. Fully variable valve actuation has been achieved and the valve motion profile is given.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In a camless engine, each valve is actuated by an independent actuator. The valve lift, the valve duration, and the valve timing can be regulated flexibly by controlling the motion of the valve actuator [1]. Therefore, fully variable valve actuation can be achieved, which makes it possible to eliminate the throttle. Instead, the load of the engine will be adjusted by regulating the valve events. The engine will aspirate with a higher efficiency, and the pumping loss will be significantly reduced. The valve events are adjusted independently of the position of the crankshaft to achieve the optimum engine performance in all operating conditions. The fully variable valve actuation technology also provides benefits such as an improved cold-start and warm-up operation [2] and reduces the idle speed, cylinder and valve deactivation, and optimized internal residual gas recirculation [3], which means that the fuel economy, the emissions, and the torque output performance of the engine can be greatly improved.

A camless valvetrain often refers to an electromagnetic valve actuator (EMVA) and an electrohydraulic valve actuator (EHVA). A typical EMVA [4–8] consists of two electromagnets, an armature, and two springs. The driving force is provided mainly by the springs. The electromagnets are used to compensate for friction losses and to hold the valves in the open or closed position. It is very difficult to regulate the seating velocity because the electromagnetic force increases rapidly when the armature is close to the core [9]. This structure also poses considerable challenges in achieving variable valve lift. An EHVA [1, 10–12] utilizes the supplied hydraulic pressure to actuate the valves by electronically controlling the solenoids. It has been reported that an EHVA has potential issues of energy consumption and the capability of generating a repeatable valve lift over the life cycle of the engine [13].
To replace the traditional valvetrain, the camless valvetrain must have the following features.

list-item.p: The maximum valve lift should meet the demand to provide sufficient charging (such as 8 mm), and the valve lift, valve duration, and valve timing should be variable.
The ability to achieve a transition time (the time in which the valve moves from 5 per cent of the travel to 95 per cent of the travel [14]) of 4 ms or faster is necessary to meet high engine speeds.
The seating velocity should be lower than 0.1 m/s [15] to reduce the acoustic noise and to increase the durability.
The effective mechanical power loss should not be higher than that of a traditional valvetrain.

sec.p: These requirements lead to challenges for control of a camless valvetrain. A variety of control methods for an EMVA have been investigated, mainly including feedback control and feedforward control. Most studies have used a combination of the two. Feedback control algorithms mainly include sensorless control [16], linearization-based control [17], Lyapunov-function-based control [18], sliding-mode control [19], and flatness-based control [15]. Typical feedforward control algorithms include iterative learning control [20] and extremum seeking control [21]. These control schemes show great promise for controlling the valve seating velocity, but they have considerable limitations in achieving a variable valve lift.

The EMVA studied in this paper is based on a moving-coil linear actuator [22]. A prototype of the EMVA has been designed and manufactured, as reported in the present authors’ previous work. The purpose of this work is to develop a control system that could achieve fully variable valve actuation using the inverse system method (ISM). The ISM was first proposed by Silverman [23] in 1968 and subsequently described by Li [24]; it has been used to achieve non-linear decoupling for non-linear systems recently [25]. It is easy to realize in engineering with a simple structure.

This paper is organized as follows. Section 2 describes the structure and dynamic model of the EMVA. In section 3, the reversibility of the EMVA system is proved, and the inverse system is established. Section 4 presents the state feedback control methodology for the pseudo-linear system. Section 5 describes the simulation model and experimental set-up. In section 6, the simulation and experimental results are compared and discussed.

sec.title: 2.1 Structure of the EMVA
sec.p: Figure 1 shows the structure and prototype of the EMVA to be controlled. The EMVA consists of a moving coil, a valve, a spring, permanent magnets, an inner core, and an outer core. The main actuator dimensions are given in Table 1. The permanent magnets are Nd–Fe–B with a maximum operating temperature of 180 °C. A Halbach magnet array is utilized to maximize the actuating force. Since the magnetic flux density is mainly provided by the permanent magnets, and the magnetic flux density produced by the coil current is negligibly small, therefore the hysteresis can be neglected. A single spring with a low stiffness is used to hold the valve closed when the power is off. When the coil is energized, the Lorentz force produced in the coil actuates the valve to move. The electromagnetic force can be bidirectional as the direction of the current changes. The moving-coil linear actuator has low electrical constants (0.54 ms) and mechanical time constants (0.68 ms). The actuating force is almost proportional to the amount of current. This creates favourable conditions to achieve accurate motion control.

sec.title: 5.1 Simulation model
sec.p: The simulations are carried out using MATLAB/Simulink to validate the proposed control algorithm. The closed-loop control architecture is shown in Fig. 4, which consists of the EMVA dynamic model, the inverse system, the state feedback controller, and a state observer. The EMVA system is modelled with equation (1). The force sensitivity is obtained from a look-up table which is obtained from the results of the FEA. The inverse system, the state feedback controller, and the state observer use equation (6), equation (8), and equation (13), independently. The feedback signals for the EMVA closed-loop controller are the valve position and the coil current. The unmeasured state variables of the pseudo-linear system, the valve velocity, and the acceleration are obtained from the state observer.

In the simulation, the combustion pressure on the exhaust valve is not taken into account, while the experiment has not been carried out on a real internal combustion engine. The EMVA parameters used for simulation are shown in Table 2.

sec.title: 5.2 Experimental set-up
sec.p: In order to verify the performance of the EMVA and to validate the proposed control algorithm, an experimental set-up was constructed. The configuration of the experimental system is shown in Fig. 5. A fixed-point TMS320F2812 DSP with a clock frequency of 150 MHz was chosen as the digital controller. In the experiment system, two EMVAs were tested. One is for the intake, and the other is for the exhaust. The EMVAs were mounted on a pseudo-cylinder. For each EMVA, a position sensor (Schaevitz 500 LCIT) with a resolution of 30 μm and a bandwidth of 1 kHz was used to provide the position feedback. The LCIT sensor was mounted by the side of the EMVA. A stem was connected to the moving coil so that the displacement could be measured. The current measurement was taken with a closed-loop Hall-effect current sensor (TBC10SY). The sampling frequency of the DSP was chosen to be 10 kHz, and the switching frequency of the PWM inverter was set to 20 kHz. The maximum supply voltage was limited to 30 V. The DSP control board, the interface circuit, the PWM inverter, and the current sensors were integrated in a control box. For precise laboratory measurement, a laser displacement sensor (Micro-Epsilon optoNCDT 2220) was also used to measure the displacement of the valve. In comparison with the LCIT, the laser displacement sensor has a higher resolution of 1.5 μm. Both the displacement and the velocity of the valve can be measured accurately. The measurements obtained from the laser displacement sensor were used to determine only the effectiveness of the controller and not the feedback control. A PC was used to receive data from the DSP, so that the motion and controlling process can be displayed.

sec.title: 6 Results and Discussion
sec.p: In this section, both the simulation and the experimental results will be given and compared.

sec.title: 6.1 Comparison of the different types of controller
sec.p: The proposed controller has been compared with a tuned double-closed-loop proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controller (a position loop and a current loop) by simulation.

sec.title: 6.1.1 Response with various reference inputs
sec.p: Figure 6 shows the system response with respect to various reference valve lifts. The reference valve lifts are step signals and are set to 4 mm, 6 mm, and 8 mm respectively. It is demonstrated that ISM control converges more quickly than PID control does, which ensures a fast transition time. The transition times of ISM control are 3.3 ms, 3.5 ms, and 3.8 ms, while those of PID control are 4.7 ms, 4.8 ms, and 4.9 ms respectively. For PID control, at a reference lift of 4 mm, the valve lift converges without an apparent overshoot since the PID controller was tuned at this point. However, 1.3 per cent and 2 per cent overshoots happen at reference lifts of 6 mm and 8 mm respectively. For ISM control, no overshoot happens at either reference lift. A large valve lift overshoot is not allowed in EMVA control, as it may cause the valve to hit the piston head or may lead to a high seating velocity.

caption.p: System response with various reference inputs

sec.title: 6.1.2 Disturbance rejection
sec.p: The EMVA suffers from various disturbances, such as combustion pressure and supercharge pressure. Since the pressure curves were not well defined in the investigation, disturbance forces F of ±100 N were applied on the valve for a time of 3–5 ms to estimate the disturbance rejection of the system. In Fig. 7, ISM control rejects 100 N force disturbances by maintaining no overshoot while PID control has up to 11 per cent overshoot. When a force disturbance of –100 N is applied, PID control has an apparent overdamping, taking a transition time of 6.9 ms. Neither an overshoot nor overdamping is allowed owing to degradation in the engine transient performance. It is shown that the performance of the disturbance rejection of ISM control is better than that of PID control.

sec.title: 6.1.3 Robustness to parameter variation
sec.p: The system parameters such as the coil resistance R can shift from the nominal values becasue of an increased temperature or some other factors. Figure 8 shows the simulation results when the values of R were increased by 20 per cent and 50 per cent respectively. When R varies, the transition times remain the same and no overshoot happens, which indicates that both ISM control and PID control are robust to parameter variations.

sec.title: 6.2 Experimental results
sec.p: The simulation results show that ISM control offers a superior performance to PID control with respect to the transition time, the disturbance rejection, and the robustness to parameter variations. Nevertheless, the performance of ISM control needs experimental validation. Figure 9 shows a valve motion profile at an engine speed of 2500 r/min. The experimental valve lift and velocity profile are illustrated and compared with the simulation results. The reference valve lift was set to 8 mm. Ten cycles of experimental valve lifts are superimposed in Fig. 9(a). The result shows that the valve profile is quite repeatable. Both the simulated and the experimental transition times for valve opening are about 3.8 ms, which corresponds to a typical valve motion at 6000 r/min engine speed. The maximum valve lift from simulation is 8.00 mm and that from experiment is 7.96 mm with an error of 0.04 mm. The experimental valve lift shows agreement with the simulation result. The simulated and experimental valve velocities are shown in Fig. 9(b). It is demonstrated that a seating velocity (the average of three sampled valve velocities before the valve reaches the closed position) of 0.02 m/s has been achieved in the simulation, and the average seating velocity from experiment is about 0.05 m/s, which is acceptable. The estimated velocity and estimation error from the state observer in the simulation are also given in Fig. 9(b). The estimated velocity converges to the simulated velocity with a maximum estimation error of 0.05 m/s, and the state observer proved effective. The operating current profile is shown in Fig. 9(c). The experimental results show agreement with the simulation results again. The maximum current is about 20 A, and the experimental Ohmic loss is about 25 W per valve.

caption.p: Comparison between simulation and experiment at 2500 r/min: (a) valve lift; (b) valve velocity with estimation error; (c) operating current

sec.p: The proposed EMVA is a fully flexible system in which the valve lift and duration can be modified by the electronic control unit. Figure 10 shows various valve lift profiles with variable valve lift and duration. The valve lifts were chosen to be 4 mm, 6 mm, and 8 mm. The chosen lifts were arbitrary and fully variable between the fully closed position and the fully open position.

caption.p: Valve lift profiles at various valve lifts and durations (1500 r/min)

sec.title: 7 Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presents the motion control of an EMVA. Unlike the existing EMVA, a continuous variable valve lift is achieved in the proposed EMVA using the moving-coil linear actuator. An ISM has been developed to ensure precise valve motion control. The simulation and experimental results demonstrate its effectiveness. Fully variable valve actuation has been achieved, including variable valve lift, timing, and duration. The valve lift can be precisely controlled with an accuracy of 0.04 mm. A transition time of 3.8 ms and a seating velocity of 0.05 m/s have also been achieved. If the proposed EMVA can be implemented on an automotive engine, it is believed that the engine performance will be significantly improved.
As future work, the implementation of this EMVA on a research engine is planned to verify the actual system performance.
